snippet: New York City residents that smell natural gas should now call the Fire Department, not Consolidated Edison. The city believes that the Fire Department will provide faster responses, thereby averting potential disasters.
abstract: New York City's Fire Department is now responding to all reports of gas odors that city receives; says residents should call 911, not Consolidated Edison; significant change in policy, which comes after gas explosion in East Harlem that leveled two buildings, stems from belief that it will provide faster responses, averting potential disasters.
lead_paragraph: New York City residents that smell natural gas should now call the Fire Department, not Consolidated Edison. The city believes that the Fire Department will provide faster responses, thereby averting potential disasters.

headline.main: Fire Dept. Is Now Responding to All Gas-Odor Calls
headline.print_headline: Fire Dept., Not Utility, Is Responding to All Gas-Odor Calls
